channel.title: ASF Jira
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [THRIFT-3301] Java generated code uses imports that can lead to class name collisions with IDL defined types
item.description:
The Java generator will produce Java classes with the following set of imports

import org.apache.thrift.scheme.IScheme;
import org.apache.thrift.scheme.SchemeFactory;
import org.apache.thrift.scheme.StandardScheme;

import org.apache.thrift.scheme.TupleScheme;
import org.apache.thrift.protocol.TTupleProtocol;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.Map;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.EnumMap;
import java.util.Set;
import java.util.HashSet;
import java.util.EnumSet;
import java.util.Collections;
import java.util.BitSet;
import java.nio.ByteBuffer;
import java.util.Arrays;
import org.slf4j.Logger;
import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;

Any one of the imported classes may cause a name conflict with generated code that happens to define a same name class and uses such class as argument or result to methods.

The generated code should always use fully qualified references to the classes when necessary and avoid all use of imports.
item.summary: Java generated code uses imports that can lead to class name collisions with IDL defined types

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Gradle example project showing the error.

Workaround for issue included in the Gradle build.gradle file for demonstration purposes.

Untar the attached file and run "./gradlew" in the resulting top level directory.

For the sake of completeness I retested this with the latest stable 0.9.2 and it fails the same way. It is possible that the most likely to have a conflict is the Logger class reference but the rest may cause issues. Thrift definitions created without Java in mind would lead to such issues. In our case the Thrift definition predated the requirement to bind with Java and thus the Logger struct was used.

Github user bgould commented on the issue:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1119

@Jens-G

IMO this is a valid use case but it is not necessarily a great idea because in general its not very user friendly to design an API that clashes names in java.lang.* ... it is even more complicated in Thrift because other languages may also have constructs called "Object" (javascript for example). There is not a Java-specific technical reason why this shouldn't be allowed however.

That said, there is a related JIRA, not exactly the same problem because java.lang classes do not require import statements, but the idea is the same:

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-3301
I would add java.lang.Object to this list, however I believe THRIFT-3954 may resolve that.

GitHub user bgould opened a pull request:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1120

THRIFT-3301: Naming collisions possible in generated Java code

Switched to fully-qualified names for all class name references in generated code. Added test IDL to verify generated code compiles successfully.

You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:

$ git pull https://github.com/bgould/thrift THRIFT-3301

Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1120.patch

To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch
with (at least) the following in the commit message:

This closes #1120

commit c6c5a054955c1b76fa498bb74388b5ddc8f36c14
Author: BCG <bgould@users.noreply.github.com>
Date: 2016-11-01T03:32:18Z

Switched to fully-qualified names for all class name references in generated code

Github user jeking3 commented on the issue:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1120

> The following tests FAILED:
> 40 - JavaTest (Failed)
> Errors while running CTest

Github user nsuke commented on the issue:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1120

@bgould the failing CI job is make dist tarball verification.
It's typically caused by missing `EXTRA_DIST` entries for newly added files in `Makefile.am`.

Github user bgould commented on the issue:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1120

Thanks @nsuke I'm pretty sure that was the problem. I created a new IDL file for validating this change, and I've now added it to tests/Makefile.am

Github user jeking3 commented on the issue:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1120

Does the cmake install job need to be updated as well?

Github user jeking3 commented on the issue:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1120

I'm not seeing why JavaTypes was introduced - was it simply used to manually check the build for output of every native type? Is the result from JavaTypes compilation used in some unit test that would fail if it didn't produce the correct output? If not, does it belong in the distribution?

Github user bgould commented on the issue:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1120

@jeking3

Yes exactly. I added it to the build process that compiles the java unit tests... so if some change to compiler introduces a regression, the IDL in that file should fail to compile. I didn't add a unit test for this as I felt that the compilation itself was the test.

Consider the following IDL:

struct String

{ 1: string val }

struct Object

{ 1: map<string, String> somemap }

It would be possible to make a modification to the compiler that erroneously generates the map type as `java.util.Map<String, String>` instead of `java.util.Map<java.lang.String, String>` or to add some reference in the generated code to `java.lang.Object` that is not fully-qualified... however with the generated classes above in the `thrift.test` package, `javac` should flag the unqualified reference(s) as ambiguous.

Github user bgould commented on the issue:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1120

Also one thing to note is that the Java code generated from following valid IDL will still fail to compile because the names match Java primitive types... I know of no way to avoid this problem:

```thrift
struct int

{ 1: i32 val }

struct boolean

{ 1: bool val }

struct long

{ 1: i64 val }

struct short

{ 1: i16 short }

struct char

{ 1: i16 val }

struct Primitives

{ 1: i32 int, 2: i64 long, 3: i16 short, 4: bool boolean, 5: i16 char }

```

Github user jeking3 commented on the issue:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1120

I think a number of those things are in the "reserved" keyword list for the thrift compiler, so that's okay. Nice, I'll mark this one approved.

Also one thing to note is that the Java code generated from following valid IDL will still fail to compile because the names match Java primitive types... I know of no way to avoid this problem:

That is part of a general problem, not only with Java. There are tickets around where people solved that already for other languages. The single biggest issue is, that (aside from a buch of really common standard keywords) there is no general set of keywords, and no generic solution. Happy are those who have the ability to escape keywords, like in C# where we can just precede keywords with a @ character to make them an identifier. Unfortunately, not all languages have such an option.

the "reserved" keyword list for the thrift Compiler

I personally tend to think of this one being a crutch, at least partially. While it makes sense to just plain forbid some keywords that are keywords in virtually all languages, it is not the solution that fits all. Adding one keyword to the list because it is a keyword in one of ~20 languages sounds just strange to me.

Upon further thought I think that the Java keyword problem could be solved by prefixing identifiers with an underscore, similar to the method Jens mentioned for C#. Such a solution might not be ideal, and I'm not sure it is necessarily the best solution, but is probably better than generating code that will not compile. I will spin off a new jira issue if one does not exist already because this issue is about the imports in generated code, not Java keywords.

+
— End diff –

Do we need the same for exception?

Github user bgould commented on a diff in the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1120#discussion_r90040582

— Diff: lib/java/test/org/apache/thrift/test/TestClient.java —

goodbye.string_thing = "Goodbye4";
goodbye.byte_thing = (byte)4;
goodbye.i32_thing = 4;

  • goodbye.i64_thing = (long)4;
    + goodbye.i64_thing = 4;

— End diff –

Yes that is unrelated... I think my IDE settings are such that it was removed automatically because it was an unncessary... no problem for me to restore it if you prefer.
